Award.AwardTitle: Multicentury Reconstruction of Tropical Climate Variability from Red Sea Corals
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, researchers aim to develop sea surface temperature and salinity records from the central Red Sea back ~400 years. The records will be generated using trace element and oxygen isotopes in coral skeletons, and will be measured in long drill cores at bi-weekly, seasonal and annual resolution. Both sea surface temperature and salinity in the Red Sea region are highly sensitive to climate forcing from the North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO). The goal of this project is to reveal long-term changes in the NAO, and determine whether patterns of NAO behavior changed during periods of sustained warm and cold mean climate.

The broader impacts involve the training and education of a female Ph.D. student and a female minority undergraduate student. Identifying a relationship between NAO behavior and mean climate would also be a substantial step toward improving our ability to predict NAO behavior in the face of future global warming.

We developed quantitative calibrations of strontium-to-calcium (Sr/Ca) ratios versus sea surface temperature (SST) for six individual coral colonies across a large SST gradient in the Red Sea. No significant differences were found between regressions for individual colonies at full seasonal resolution, and data for all six corals were combined into a single regression to provide a calibration equation applicable to the entire region. We also found strong and significant regressions for both winter and summer averaged data, demonstrating the potential for quantitative reconstructing past SST as a function of season. Together, these results demonstrate the power of coral Sr/Ca as an SST proxy across a range of temporal and spatial scales, and thus the potential to reconstruct spatial SST patterns back through time. We have reconstructed SST over the past ~230 years from two locations in the northern and central Red Sea, showing pronounced decadal-centennial scale variability in the full seasonal cycle as well as winter and summer seasons separately. Winter season SST shows a strong correlation to the North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) at multidecadal time scales, and combining these records with other centuries-long NAO reconstructions reveals changes in geographic stationarity of the NAO signal back through time. Winter-season SSTs in the northern and central Red Sea also show a striking pattern of antiphase decadal-centennial scale changes over the entire 230-year record. The SST gradient appears to undergo a cycle of collapse, followed by abrupt strengthening and subsequent gradual weakening before another collapse. Climate data and models indicate that the Red Sea SST gradient is driven by meridional wind intensity, and our records represent a new discovery of changes in wind intensity potentially occurring on a ~170-year cycle. In addition, we have developed coral barium-to-calcium (Ba/Ca) ratios as a novel proxy for eolian dust deposition. Two corals from the central and southern Red Sea show nearly identical records of Ba/Ca in seawater, reflecting changes in Summer Asian Monsoon wind intensity over the past ~230 years. The coral monsoon records show periodic variability at interannual to multidecadal frequencies that is strongly anticorrelated with Northern Hemisphere mean temperature. This suggests that monsoon variability (though not intensity) should continue to decline in the face of continued anthropogenic warming in the future. On-going global climate change is a significant problem facing society. In particular, coherent modes of coupled ocean-atmosphere variability, such as the NAO or Asian Monsoon, affect billions of people around the globe, and observations of the long-term behavior of these systems are critical to understanding the mechanisms controlling their change. Our records of NAO variability indicate that the spatial pattern of climate change associated with this oscillation has changed through time, and thus caution must be used when interpreting paleo-NAO records from a limited spatial area.
